data.title: SKY Italia gets rights to show 2014 and 2016 Olympics
data.meta_description:
OCTOBER 21 - RUPERT MURDOCH'S SATELLITE COMPANY SKY ITALIA WILL
BROADCAST THE 2014 WINTER OLYMPICS AND 2016 SUMMER GAMES IN ITALY, IT
WAS ANNOUNCED TODAY.
data.text:
The $109 million (£67.1 million) deal announced by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) requires the company to offer coverage on free-to-air television as well as its pay channels, and through the internet and mobile phones.

IOC President Jacques Rogge said: "Our aim is to ensure that as many people as possible are able to enjoy the sporting action on all broadcast platforms."

Sky Italia is a wholly owned subsidiary of Murdoch's News Corporation.

It has already been awarded the Italian rights to show the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver and the 2012 Games in London.

Last month Sky cut a controversial deal for 2010 and 2012 with public broadcaster RAI which will see them will offer Sky Italia the chance to share the TV rights to the football World Cups in 2010 and 2014.

Under the agreement, RAI will transmit a total of 315 hours of Olympics on its free-to-air channels, while Sky will broadcast the World Cup on seven of its channels.

The 2014 Winter Olympics are being held in Sochi.

The IOC will choose the 2016 host at its Session in Copenhagen on October 2 when it will choose from a short-list of Chicago, Madrid, Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo.
